questions.prompt: Why does Arjuna ask again in BG 5.1 which path is superior, despite Krishna's previous explanations?
choices: Arjuna has forgotten everything Krishna taught in previous chapters
The relativist claim that all paths are equally valid spiritually
Krishna deliberately confuses Arjuna with contradictory teachings
The dualistic error of seeing renunciation and action as contradictory
questions.feedback: Arjuna still perceives sannyasa and karma-yoga as separate paths, not grasping their unity: both require detachment-true renunciation is internal attitude, not external inactivity.

questions.prompt: According to BG 5.2, which path does Krishna recommend as superior?
choices: Complete renunciation of all activities without exception
Work in devotion is superior to formal renunciation
Neither path leads to liberation from material bondage
Both paths are equally easy for all practitioners
questions.feedback: Krishna recommends karma-yoga (work in devotion) as superior to mere renunciation, though both can lead to the goal.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 5.3, what does Srila Prabhupada explain about the renouncer's attitude?
choices: The renouncer must physically abandon all possessions immediately
Renunciation requires intense austerity and constant suffering
Neither desires nor laments; everything for Krishna's pleasure
True renunciation means hating all material objects and activities
questions.feedback: A devotee in Krishna consciousness neither desires nor laments anything material-working only for Krishna's satisfaction, not personal enjoyment.

questions.prompt: Why does BG 5.6 state that work without yoga keeps one bound?
choices: The activist misconception that good works alone guarantee spiritual progress
Physical labor itself creates bondage through material engagement
Yoga connects work to God; without connection, karma binds
The ascetic fallacy that mere external renunciation liberates automatically
questions.feedback: Work performed without yogic connection to Krishna accumulates karmic reactions; yoga (union) transforms work from binding karma to liberating service-the connection, not cessation, frees.

questions.prompt: According to BG 5.7, what characterizes the transcendental person?
choices: They are unaffected by joy or sorrow, are self-controlled
They enjoy pleasures heavily through unrestricted sense gratification
They are consistently angry due to material frustrations
They are easily disturbed by external circumstances and events
questions.feedback: The transcendentalist remains balanced in success and failure.

questions.prompt: How does the transcendentalist's use of senses (BG 5.8) differ from the sensualist's use?
choices: Consciousness determines whether senses bind or liberate
The dualist error that senses themselves are inherently sinful
Transcendentalists simply have stronger willpower to resist temptation
The ascetic misconception that total sense suppression equals spirituality
questions.feedback: Same senses, different consciousness: sensualist uses for self-gratification (binding), transcendentalist engages for Krishna's service (liberating)-senses themselves neutral, directed by will.

questions.prompt: What does BG 5.9 teach about one who engages in devotional service?
choices: They suffer more due to increased awareness of material misery
They remain bound by the reactions of their devotional work
They are quickly freed from karma and attain peace
They accumulate more karma through continued material activities
questions.feedback: Devotional service swiftly purifies the soul and removes all impurities.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 5.10, what does Srila Prabhupada explain about the lotus leaf analogy?
choices: The devotee completely avoids all contact with material world
Like lotus untouched by water, devotee unaffected by sin
The lotus represents material entanglement and attachment
Water destroys lotus just as sin destroys spiritual life
questions.feedback: Like a lotus leaf in water remains untouched, the devotee engaged in Krishna's service is unaffected by sinful reactions.

questions.prompt: In BG 5.11, who is a true renunciate according to Krishna?
choices: One who not works through independent material processes
One who leaves home through independent material processes
One who has conquered the senses and mind
One who lives in poverty accepting no possessions
questions.feedback: True renunciation is mastery over mind and senses, not external appearance.

questions.prompt: How does offering work's results to Krishna (BG 5.12) free one from karmic reactions?
choices: Krishna takes responsibility for devotees' actions mechanically
The legalistic view that correct procedure satisfies cosmic requirements
The magical thinking that ritual offering nullifies material consequences
Offering transfers ownership; what's Krishna's doesn't bind the offerer
questions.feedback: When work is done for Krishna and results offered to Him, the doer becomes instrument not proprietor-reactions accrue to the enjoyer/owner, not the tool; offering shifts agency from self to Krishna.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 5.13, what does Srila Prabhupada explain about the nine-gated city?
choices: Body with nine openings houses the soul who isn't the doer
The material world itself is described as a nine-gated city
Nine gates represent nine different types of material knowledge
The city has nine gates for different sense gratification activities
questions.feedback: The body (nine-gated city) houses the soul who remains aloof from bodily activities-the soul is occupant, not actor in material engagements.

questions.prompt: In BG 5.14, who is truly liberated according to Krishna?
choices: The famous who are celebrated throughout society everywhere
The powerful who control others through their influence and authority
The wealthy who possess abundant material opulence and resources
One who has transcended ego and false identification
questions.feedback: Liberation comes from renouncing the false ego and bodily identification.

questions.prompt: What does BG 5.15 teach about attaining peace?
choices: Peace requires isolation from all external contact entirely
Peace is impossible to achieve in the material world
Peace comes from gratification of material desires gradually
Peace comes through self-knowledge and surrender to Krishna
questions.feedback: True peace comes from knowing the eternal nature of the soul.

questions.prompt: How does knowledge destroy doubts and liberate according to BG 5.16?
choices: Accumulating facts about spiritual topics gradually removes ignorance
The gnostic error that secret information grants automatic salvation
Transcendental knowledge reveals soul's nature, dispelling illusion
The rationalist assumption that intellectual understanding alone liberates
questions.feedback: Not mere information but realized knowledge of soul's eternality and Krishna's supremacy destroys the ignorance causing material identification-this awakening to reality dissolves doubts born of illusion.

questions.prompt: How does the teaching that karma-yoga and sannyasa reach the same goal (BG 5.4-5) relate to the yogi's equal vision (BG 5.18-19)?
choices: The relativist error that all paths are equally valid regardless of consciousness
The dualist misconception that action and knowledge exist separately
Both paths cultivate detachment enabling perception of soul in all beings
The elitist view that renunciation is inherently superior to work
questions.feedback: Whether through renunciation or work in devotion, the goal is transcending false identification with body-modes-ego. This purification enables equal vision: seeing the eternal soul (and Supersoul) in all bodies regardless of species or caste. The realized person sees through bodily designations (learned brahmana, outcaste, cow, dog, elephant) to the common spiritual essence. Both paths work because both develop detachment from material distinctions.

questions.prompt: How does understanding that modes control action (BG 5.14-15) integrate with the self-realized person's detachment (BG 5.7-12)?
choices: The libertarian assumption that understanding modes grants autonomy
Recognizing modes as controllers dispels false doership, enabling surrender
The determinist error that mode-control eliminates all responsibility
The quietist misconception that knowledge of modes justifies inaction
questions.feedback: Understanding the body acts by modes' compulsion (not soul's independent choice) destroys false ego's claim 'I am the doer'-this isn't fatalism but liberation from the arrogance that binds. The self-realized person acts through body-senses but identifies as Krishna's instrument rather than independent agent, offering results to Him. Detachment flows from correct understanding of actual agency: modes act on body, soul serves Krishna.

questions.prompt: Why does Prabhupada (BG 5.6 purport) say Mayavadi sannyasis' Brahman speculation becomes tedious while Krishna consciousness remains fresh?
choices: The impersonal void lacks relational dynamics to sustain interest
The sentimentalist error that emotion matters more than truth
Both eventually become tedious; all spiritual practice is difficult
Brahman realization is superior but requires more qualification
questions.feedback: Impersonal speculation targets featureless void-no reciprocation, no variety, no love possible; tedium inevitable. Krishna consciousness engages personality in unlimited relational exchange with infinite Person-ever-fresh because the soul's nature is relationship, not isolation. Mayavadis' falldown to material philanthropy reveals void's inadequacy.

questions.prompt: How does understanding the distinction between bodily and spiritual identity (BG 5.5-7) enable transcendental happiness (BG 5.21-24)?
choices: The ascetic error that rejecting bodily pleasure automatically creates bliss
Spiritual identification frees from bodily dependencies, revealing internal joy
The hedonist misconception that maximizing pleasure brings satisfaction
The stoic fallacy that suppressing desire equals contentment
questions.feedback: Bodily identification makes happiness depend on external contact (sense objects, others' approval, material conditions)-ever unstable and ultimately disappointing. Spiritual identity recognizes the self as soul, not body-happiness comes from within (atma-rati), independent of circumstances. This isn't denial of bodily reality but correct prioritization: body serves soul's purpose (Krishna consciousness), not soul enslaved to body's demands. Internal satisfaction makes external conditions irrelevant.

questions.prompt: How does the teaching that the embodied soul is not the doer (BG 5.8-9, 5.14) relate to offering work's fruits to Krishna (BG 5.10, 5.12)?
choices: The antinomian view that realized souls act without consequences
The quietist error that non-doership justifies complete inaction
The determinist misconception that no one is responsible for anything
Recognizing modes as agents enables offering Krishna what's actually His
questions.feedback: Understanding 'I am not the doer' (modes acting through body) dispels false proprietorship-if I'm not the real agent, I'm not the real owner of results either. This enables genuine offering: presenting to Krishna what He's producing through His energies (nature, body, intelligence) rather than taking credit and enjoying separately. False doership claims results; correct understanding offers them. Liberation comes through alignment with reality.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 5.29, what does Srila Prabhupada explain is the greatest peace formula?
choices: Lord Krsna is beneficiary of all human activities
Independent material prosperity brings lasting peace and happiness
Becoming one with the impersonal Brahman effulgence
Understanding oneself as supreme controller of material nature
questions.feedback: The greatest peace formula: Krsna is beneficiary, proprietor of all planets, greater than all demigods.

questions.prompt: How does Prabhupada's peace formula (BG 5.29 purport)-Krishna as proprietor, beneficiary, friend-address global conflicts over resources, nationalism, and competing interests?
choices: The utopian error that religion alone solves political problems
Recognizing true Owner/Enjoyer dissolves false proprietorship conflicts
The secular view that separating religion from politics brings peace
The pluralist hope that respecting all beliefs creates harmony
questions.feedback: Conflicts arise from false proprietorship: 'my country, my resources, my rights.' Realizing Krishna owns everything, humans are tenants not owners, and His pleasure is goal-removes competition's root. Nations fight over what's 'theirs'; devotees cooperate over Krishna's property. No peace without recognizing actual proprietor.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 5.18, what does Srila Prabhupada explain about equal vision?
choices: Differences of body are meaningless to learned transcendentalist
Species and castes have equal spiritual value and importance
Bodies of brahmana and outcaste are equal in spiritual reality
Material distinctions define spiritual advancement and realization actually
questions.feedback: Body differences are meaningless from viewpoint of learned transcendentalist due to relationship with Paramatma in everyone's heart.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 5.18, what false conception does Srila Prabhupada clarify?
choices: Soul's quantity increases with spiritual advancement and practice
Similarity in quality doesn't make them equal in quantity
Parammatma is only in brahmanical bodies of qualified souls
Individual soul and Supersoul are equal in quantity always
questions.feedback: Soul and Supersoul similar in quality (conscious, eternal, blissful) but not equal in quantity - soul in one body, Paramatma in all.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 5.6, what does Srila Prabhupada say about those engaged in Krsna conscious activities?
choices: Better situated than sannyasis in simple speculation
They need Brahman speculation for advancement in knowledge
They must speculate about Brahman first before devotion
Simple renunciation is superior to devotional service activities
questions.feedback: Those engaged in Krsna consciousness are better situated than sannyasis engaged in simple Brahman speculation.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 5.29, what does Srila Prabhupada say about achieving peace?
choices: Individual effort alone brings lasting peace to everyone
Peace comes through controlling others and their actions
Material adjustment leads to collective peace for all
Not possible without understanding Krsna's position as master
questions.feedback: Unless one understands bare facts (Krsna master, souls subordinate), not possible to achieve peace individually or collectively.
